Definitions
Definitions

Segmentation is the partitioning of an image into regions that are homogeneous with respect to some characteristics.
Segmentation is the partitioning of an image into
regions that are homogeneous with respect to some r e g i o n s
t h a t
a r e
h o m o g e n e o u s w i t h
r e s p e c t
t o
s o m e
characteristics. c h a r a c t e r i s t i c s .

In medical context: •
In medical context:
•

Segmentation is the delineation of anatomical structures and other regions of interest, i.e. lesions, tumors.
Segmentation is the delineation of anatomical
structures and other regions of interest, i.e. lesions,
tumors.

More Definitions
More Definitions

Determining the total number of sets K can be a challenging problem.
Determining the total number of sets K can be a
challenging problem.

In medical imaging, the number of sets is often based on a-priori knowledge of anatomy, e.g. K=3 (gray, white, CSF) for brain imaging.
In medical imaging, the number of sets is often based
on a-priori knowledge of anatomy, e.g. K=3 (gray,
white, CSF) for brain imaging.

Labeling
Labeling

Labeling is the process of assigning a meaningful designation to each region or pixel.
Labeling is the process of assigning a meaningful
designation to each region or pixel.

This process is often performed separately from segmentation.
This process is often performed separately from
segmentation.

Generally, computer-automated labeling is desirable
Generally, computer-automated labeling is desirable

Labeling and sets Zk may not necessarily share a one- to-one correspondence
Labeling and sets Zk may not necessarily share a one- L a b e l i n g

Dimensionality
Dimensionality

Dimensionality refers to whether the segmentation operates in a 2D or 3D domain.
Dimensionality refers to whether the segmentation
operates in a 2D or 3D domain.

Generally, 2D methods are applied to 2D images and 3D methods to 3D images.
Generally, 2D methods are applied to 2D images and
3D methods to 3D images.

In some instances, 2D methods can be applied sequentially to 3D images.
In some instances, 2D methods can be applied
sequentially to 3D images. s e q u e n t i a l l y
t o
3 D
i m a g e s .

Characteristic and Membership Functions
Characteristic and Membership
Functions

A characteristic function is an indicator whether a pixel at location j belongs to a particular class Zk.
A characteristic function is an indicator whether a pixel at location
j belongs to a particular class Zk. j
b e l o n g s
t o
a
p a r t i c u l a r
c l a s s
Z k .

This can be generalized to a membership function, which does not have to be binary valued.
This can be generalized to a membership function, which does
not have to be binary valued.

The characteristic function describes a “deterministic” segmentation process whereas the membership function describes a “probabilistic” one.

Region Growing: Principle Limitations
Region Growing: Principle Limitations

• Segmentation results dependent on seed selection • Local variability dominates the growth process • Global features are ignored
• Segmentation results dependent on seed selection
• Local variability dominates the growth process
• Global features are ignored

• Generalization needed:
• Generalization needed:

– Unsupervised segmentation (i.e.insensitive to selection of seeds) – Exploitation of both local and global variability
– Unsupervised segmentation (i.e.insensitive to selection of seeds)
– Exploitation of both local and global variability

Clustering: Principle Limitations
Clustering: Principle Limitations

• Convergence to the optimal configuration is not
• Convergence to the optimal configuration is not

guaranteed.
guaranteed.

• Outcome depends on the number of clusters chosen. • No easy control over balancing global and local
• Outcome depends on the number of clusters chosen.
• No easy control over balancing global and local

variability Intrinsic assumption of a uniform feature probability is still being made
variability
Intrinsic assumption of a uniform feature probability is
still being made

• Generalization needed:
• Generalization needed:

– Relax requirement to predetermine number of classes – Balance influence of global and local variability – Possibility to including a-priori information, such as non-uniform
– Relax requirement to predetermine number of classes
– Balance influence of global and local variability
– Possibility to including a-priori information, such as non-uniform

distribution of features.
distribution of features.

Deformable Models
Deformable Models

• So far segmentation methods have not exploited
• So far segmentation methods have not exploited

knowledge of shape.
knowledge of shape.

In shape based methods, the segmentation problem is again formulated as an energy-minimization problem. However, a curve evolves in the image until it reaches the lowest energy state instead of a MRF.
In shape based methods, the segmentation problem
is again formulated as an energy-minimization
problem. However, a curve evolves in the image until
it reaches the lowest energy state instead of a MRF.

• External and internal forces deform the shape control
• External and internal forces deform the shape control
